Some of you may be interested in a short paper I wrote describing
Cantera for the upcoming Paris Electrochemical Society CVD meeting. The
paper is:

D. G. Goodwin, "An open-source, extensible software suite for CVD
process simulation," Proceedings of CVD XVI and EuroCVD Fourteen,
Electrochemical Society, 2003 (in press).

A preprint is available at
http://blue.caltech.edu/cantera_dist/doc/cantera_ecs2003.pdf.


Here are a few answers to recent questions:

1. I haven't installed Visual Studio .NET yet, so don't know if there
are issues getting Cantera to compile with it.

2. Cantera may not work with Matlab 5 (haven't tried it). Also, if you
are using a Matlab 6 version other than the one used to build the Matlab
toolbox in the release, you will need to rebuild the Matlab toolbox.
This can be done from within Matlab. You need a C compiler configured to
work in Matlab (do 'mex -setup'). Go to the Cantera toolbox directory,
and type 'buildwin' or 'buildunix'.

3. The new version of Cantera no longer requires setting environment
variables under Windows. (But for what its worth, in Windows 98 you have
to edit AUTOEXEC.BAT and reboot. A better solution: upgrade to Win 2000
or Win XP...)

4. Chemical equilibrium calculations require a sufficient number of
species in the reaction mechanism. Otherwise, method 'equilibrate' will
fail with an error message. At a minimum, you need as many species as
elements, and these must span 'element space.' That is, any mixture
elemental composition must be achievable for some set of species mole
fractions. 

Also, compositions that correspond to exactly stoichiometric combustion
often cause 'equilibrate' to fail to converge, since the equilibrium
composition is a very sensitive function of equivalence ratio here. The
solution is to move away a very small amount from this composition.
